extendedIngredients.name: swordfish
extendedIngredients.original: 1 pound fresh swordfish, cut into chunks

title: Spicy Swordfish
summary: Spicy Swordfish requires around 50 minutes from start to finish. One serving contains 338 calories, 24g of protein, and 22g of fat. This caveman, gluten free, dairy free, and primal recipe serves 4 and costs $3.28 per serving. It works well as a main course. This recipe is liked by 1 foodies and cooks. A mixture of chili powder, onion, mango, and a handful of other ingredients are all it takes to make this recipe so flavorful. To use up the mango you could follow this main course with the Paleo Mango Scones with Mango Butter as a dessert. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 60%. This score is pretty good. Spicy Grilled Swordfish, Penne Rigate with Spicy Braised Swordfish, and Grilled Swordfish With Spicy Tropical Sauce are very similar to this recipe.

winePairing.pairingText: Fish works really well with Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. One wine you could try is Maysaran Arsheen Pinot Gris. It has 4.5 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 18 dollars.

productMatches.title: Maysara Arsheen Pinot Gris
productMatches.description: A bright expression of fruit right up front, greeting your palate with notes of cut grass on a warm day. The wine is anchored by crisp acidity, but not so much as to overpower a fleeting tease of sweetness that leaves you smiling. Arsheen has a smart, refreshing character that will bestow clarity to a range of preparations of fish, fowl, and pork.

instructions: In a medium saucepan, blend coconut milk with ginger, red onion, chili powder, and salt. Mix in mango, and bring to a boil.                            Place swordfish chunks into the coconut extract mixture, and reduce heat. Taking care not to break up the swordfish chunks, cook, stirring occasionally, 25 to 30 minutes, until the mixture is thickened and fish is easily flaked with a fork.                                                Kitchen-Friendly View

steps.step: In a medium saucepan, blend coconut milk with ginger, red onion, chili powder, and salt.
Mix in mango, and bring to a boil.

Place swordfish chunks into the coconut extract mixture, and reduce heat. Taking care not to break up the swordfish chunks, cook, stirring occasionally, 25 to 30 minutes, until the mixture is thickened and fish is easily flaked with a fork.
